3 Issues:

  • The location and interpretation of data
  • Informed consent, privacy, and the de-identification of data
  • The management, classification, and storage of data

6 principles:

  1. Learning analytics as moral practice - focusing not only on what is effective, but on what is appropriate and morally necessary.
  2. Students as agents - to be engaged as collaborators and not as mere recipients of interventions and services.
  3. Student identity and performance as temporal dynamic constructs - recognizing that analytics provides a snapshot view of a learner at a particular time and context.
  4. Students success as a complex, multidimensional phenomenon.
  5. Transparency as important - regarding the purposes for which data will be used, under what conditions, access to data, and the protection of an individual’s identity.
  6. That higher education cannot afford not to use data.

Social network analysis will be a good reference for SEL system, Educators could select and engage students into different group activities, based on their social network performance. For example, student who has a few interaction/relationship with others could be engaged into small group in which teacher as the leader of activity instead of students.

I do think students should have their own study dataset. Although we are at the same college ( to some degree we should say that our qualities are similar), we are good in different fields (e.g., our different majors). Therefore, even if we are in the same class, some people will learn, understand, and master knowledge faster than others. However, it does not mean they are smarter people. It is possible that people have different study styles or processes so that makes differences.
I think if people have their own study data, they would know much more about themselves and increase their confidence.
Most of these similar apps/programs focus on and are good at STEM education. However, how about art education? social skills? communication?

Technical, pedagogical, and social domains must be brought into dialogue with each other to ensure that interventions and organizational systems serve the needs of all stakeholders.

Def. of EDM & LAK

EDM: Educational Data Mining is an emerging discipline, concerned with developing methods for exploring the unique types of data that come from educational settings, and using those methods to better understand students, and the settings which they learn in.

LAK: the measurement, collection, analysis and reporting of data about learners and their contexts, for purposes of understanding and optimizing learning and the environments in which it occurs.

Similarities & Differences --> Table 1

EDM & LAK learn from each other.
